data.text: Contents
Use of Methoxyflurane (Penthrox®) in the Emergency Department / 17009/ 2.0
Page  of
Introduction
This purpose of this clinical policy is to ensure the appropriate prescribing and use of methoxyflurane (Penthrox®) at Broomfield Hospital

Recognition and alleviation of pain in the emergency department should be a priority. As per the RCEM standard, analgesia should be provided to those with moderate to severe pain within 20 minutes of arrival.

Methoxyflurane (Penthrox®) is a fast onset, inhaled, non-opioid analgesic intended for the emergency treatment of pain. It induces muscle relaxation and reduces pain sensitivity by modulating tissue excitability.

Penthrox is licensed for the emergency relief of moderate to severe pain in conscious adult patients with trauma and associated pain. It must not be used for mild pain or any pain associated with causes other than trauma.
Scope
This policy is to be used by all doctors, nurses,  pharmacists, and allied health professionals working in the Emergency Department of Broomfield Hospital.
This  policy  covers  adult  patients  (aged   years  and  above)  requiring emergency relief of moderate to severe pain associated with trauma who attend the Emergency Department.
It is not intended for use outside of the Emergency Department.
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities
Deputy Chief Pharmacist/ Head of Pharmacy to oversee the implementation of the guideline.
ED Clinical Lead to oversee implementation and appropriate training of clinicians
ED Matrons to oversee implementation and appropriate training of nursing staff
Administration
Refer to Appendix 1 – How to Use Penthrox.
See full dosing information/administration instructions in package leaflet and/or the SPC (via www.medicines.org.uk) and/or the BNF (via the intranet homepage or www.medicinescomplete.com).
Penthrox should be self-administered under supervision of a person trained in its administration, using the handheld Penthrox inhaler.
A copy of the patient information leaflet (PIL) and alert card should be provided to all patients receiving Penthrox (available in each pack of Penthrox®).
Patients must be advised to inhale and exhale through the custom-built Penthrox inhaler to avoid unnecessary exposure of staff to any methoxyflurane gas.
Any staff member supervising administration of Penthrox® should be trained appropriately in the use of the inhaler before undertaking supply.
A list of medical and nursing staff who have been appropriately trained in the use of Penthrox® will be held in the ED.
Methoxyflurane should not exceed greater than 6mL in a single day and/or a total of 15mL per week- administration on consecutive days is not recommended).
Contra-indications

Always refer to the Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC) (via www.medicines.org.uk) and/or the British National Formulary (BNF) (https://bnf.nice.org.uk/) for full information on contraindications and prescribing.
Pain that is not associated with trauma.
Contraindications for Penthrox are:
Patients with learning difficulties, physical disability or other problem affecting their ability to use the device;
of age;
Mild pain (only to be used in moderate to severe pain associated with trauma);
Patients outside of the emergency department (except transfer to X-Ray)
Use as an anaesthetic agent ;
Hypersensitivity to methoxyflurane (or any fluorinated anaesthetic)
Malignant hyperthermia (either known or with a genetic susceptibility);
Head injury or reduced consciousness due to any cause, including alcohol/drugs;
Clinically significant renal impairment;
Clinically evident respiratory depression;
Clinically evident cardiac instability;
Recent use of methoxyflurane (not to exceed greater than 6mL in a single day and/or a total of 15mL per week- administration on consecutive days is not recommended);

Ensure patient is not taking CYP-450 enzyme inducers (e.g. isoniazid, phenobarbital, rifampacin) and antibiotics with known nephrotoxic effect (gentamicin, tetracycline, colistin, polymyxin B, amphotericin B);
No availability of staff trained in the administration of Penthrox®;
Patients or patients with known family history of severe adverse reactions after being administered inhaled anaesthetics;
Patients who have a history of showing signs of liver damage after previous halogenated hydrocarbon anaesthesia.
Special Precautions
Always refer to the SPC (via www.medicines.org.uk) and/or the BNF (https://bnf.nice.org.uk/) for full information on contraindications and prescribing.
Elderly patients can be very sensitive to the drug and become deeply sedated.
More susceptible to reduction in blood pressure.
May increase risk of nephrotoxicity of methoxyflurane.
Patients with underlying hepatic conditions, or at risk of hepatic dysfunction.
Patients with known risk factors for renal disease and in patients diagnosed with clinical conditions that would pre-dispose to renal injury.
CNS effects such as sedation may limit use. These effects may also be a risk factor for potential abuse.
Use of methoxyflurane in the preceding 3 months.
Penthrox should not be taken on consecutive days, and not exceed 15ml in a week (check for use prior to arrival in hospital).
Increased risk of hepatic injury if used more than once inmonths.

Healthcare professionals who are regularly exposed to patients using Penthrox inhalers should be aware of any relevant occupational health and safety guidelines for use of inhalational agents, and ensure the patient always uses the activated carbon chamber.
Monitoring Requirements
Common side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, euphoria, dysarthria, amnesia, anxiety, taste disturbance, headache, nausea, paraesthesia, hypotension, cough, sweating.
Patients should be advised not to drive or operate machinery if they are affected by dizziness or drowsiness.
Disposal
Inhalers are for single patient use only.
After use, the Penthrox inhaler and used bottle must be disposed of in a sealed plastic bag (provided in pack) in the appropriate clinical waste bin.
Incidents
Any evidence of non-compliance with this policy must be reported on Datix.
Training Requirements

Any staff member supervising administration of Penthrox® should be trained in-house appropriately (training currently being provided by manufacturer) in the use of the inhaler before undertaking supply.
List of medical and nursing staff who have been appropriately trained in the use of Penthrox® will be held in the ED
Monitoring and Audit

Issues of Penthrox® in the Emergency Department will be periodically monitored by pharmacy to ensure usage is not too high. Any issues/ concerns will be highlighted to the Trauma Lead in the Emergency Department.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Monitor the use of Penthrox outside of ED
Monitor supply of Penthrox inhalers to ED
Annual (to be completed on the induction of new staff)

data.text: Approval and Implementation
Following ratification this document will be published to the Intranet and disseminated via communications through the ED.

The policy will be made available on the Trust's intranet & website by Governance. The Adult Safeguarding and Patient Safety Group will be responsible for issuing copies to all senior managers, and ward sisters for dissemination within their departments.
The approved policy will be notified in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via e-mail to all staff.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 2)
References
SPC/PIL for Penthrox 3ml inhalation vapour, liquid. Accessed via www.medicines.org.uk on 23/04/2020
Appendix 1: How to use Penthrox®
This  information  is  intended  to  be  used  alongside  counselling  by  a  healthcare professional trained in the use of Penthrox®.
